The curtains were sky-blue, the same shade as the ichthyosaur fossil display at the Natural History Museum. Above my bed I’d tacked up three things I loved most: a hand-drawn poster of Darwin’s finches, a small kite my classmate Leslie gave me, and a picture of Paddington Bear with a slice of marmalade toast.

My bedspread was white with tiny dinosaur footprints in green and blue. At the foot of the bed sat my telescope on a tripod, where I aimed at clouds and birds from my window each afternoon. On one side stood my fish tank—guppies and angelfish darting among plastic plants—which glowed gently at night. Opposite it were two wooden shelves holding Colonel Rock the turtle’s tank, my gecko terrariums labeled “Leopard” and “Cleopatra,” and, below them, my collection of beetle jars (three flower beetles, two rhinoceros beetles, two ground beetles, a giraffe stag beetle and, since my eighth birthday, a rainbow stag beetle).

In one corner I’d built an art station: a low table with jars of paint, brushes, a stack of canvases, and Owen-style “found” materials—pinecones, twigs, old soda-bottle caps—ready for my next wild splatter creation. Beside it lay my cooking corner, where I kept a small enamel pot and measuring spoons, so I could try new marmalade-on-toast experiments before breakfast.

My play area was under the window, on a soft rug shaped like a leaf. There I stored my fossil kit—Jurassic-era insect imprints, petrified wood and teeth of prehistoric beasts—as well as my cooking books on a tiny bookshelf next to a model of the ichthyosaur skull I assembled myself. That corner felt almost magical, the place I went when I wanted to discover the secrets of the world, just like Mary Anning.

Every toy, every color and picture in my room reminded me of something I loved—nature’s mysteries, distant lands, and the joy of creating. It was exactly the sort of room I wished for: a place both to dream and to tinker, all my favorite things gathered under one spring-green roof.

follow_ups.question: What part of that place or detail makes you the happiest?
follow_ups.answer: The moment that makes me happiest is standing right beneath that giant ichthyosaur skeleton in Hintze Hall.  It’s the way its long jaw stretches almost across the ceiling, every tooth and rib bone suspended above you, that fills me with pure wonder.  I love tracing its vertebrae with my eyes and imagining how this creature once sliced through warm Jurassic seas.  That instant—when past and present collide in front of your eyes—is simply magical.

follow_ups.question: Can you share a story that happened there?
follow_ups.answer:
Yes. I remember one Wednesday afternoon in Marco’s Religious Studies class when he surprised us all by arranging a visit to the little mosque just around the corner from school. He gathered our class at the gate after lunch and reminded us to take off our shoes before stepping inside. My heart was thumping—I’d never been so close to a place of worship before.

Inside, the prayer hall was hushed and cool. Sunlight filtered through stained-glass windows, casting coloured patterns on the carpet. Marco introduced us to Imam Khalid, who led us through the ritual of wudu—washing hands, arms, face and feet in a special fountain. I felt the cold water run over my wrists and shivered with excitement.

Then Imam Khalid showed us how to recite a few lines of the call to prayer in Arabic. He spoke so clearly, each word echoing in the high ceiling. When I tried to repeat it, I stumbled over the sounds, and everyone giggled kindly—except Marco, who gave me an encouraging nod.

Afterwards, we sat in a circle on the carpet while the Imam explained Ramadan and its meaning. Then he brought out sweet dates and rose-flavoured water for us to taste. The dates were so sticky and sweet that a few of us made funny faces, but I secretly loved them.

On the walk back to school, I felt as though I’d carried a little piece of that quiet mosque with me—its cool calm and the rich sound of those Arabic words. That afternoon is the first time I really understood how faith can feel like a hidden treasure chest, full of customs and kindness I’d never known before.

follow_ups.question: If that spot had its own soundtrack, what sounds or music would you hear?
follow_ups.answer:
I think of that mist-shrouded corner of Richmond Park—where I first saw the raven drinking at the pond—and if it had its own soundtrack, I’d hear:

• A low, steady sigh of wind through the tall grasses and ancient oaks, like gentle cello notes   
• Soft, high twittering from a hidden skylark or green woodpecker, a sort of flute trill echoing across the clearing   
• The distant thud of a deer’s hoof on damp earth, almost like a slow drumbeat signaling its passage   
• An occasional sharp, clarion cry of a raptor overhead, like a trumpet call cutting through the hush   
• Underneath it all, a quiet hum of ambient strings—cellos and violas—rising and falling with the light and mist   
• And every now and then, the almost imperceptible rustle of leaves and bracken as small creatures move unseen, like a whisper in the wings of the music

follow_ups.question: What time of day do you like being there best, and what makes it special?
follow_ups.answer: I like being in Hampstead Heath just after sunrise, when the park is still wrapped in morning mist and almost empty of people. That hour—around seven o’clock—feels magical to me. The air is crisp, the grass is heavy with dew, and the birds are at their liveliest: I’ve heard woodpeckers drumming, watched robins hunting worms, and even spotted a kestrel hovering over the fields. Everyone else is still waking up, so it’s almost as if the park belongs to me alone. I can lie on the grass, binoculars in hand, and watch the world come to life in silence. Those first golden rays through the trees make every leaf sparkle, and it always reminds me why I love being out in nature.

follow_ups.question: If this place could do one magical thing, what would it be?
follow_ups.answer: I remember that little Turkish mobile library with Yusuf parked by the school garden, all its shelves crammed with books from Istanbul to Anatolia. If that library could do one truly magical thing, I’d wish that every time someone opened one of its books, the pages would unfurl into a living doorway. You’d step right through the cover and find yourself wandering those narrow stone streets of Cappadocia, breathing the spice-scented air of a Grand Bazaar stall, or drifting above the fairy-chimney valleys in a hot-air balloon—all before you turned the page to return. That way, every story wouldn’t just be something you read—it would be a place you’d actually visit.

follow_ups.question: Who would you invite to join you there, and what would you do together?
follow_ups.answer:
I would ask two of my closest friends—Gerald and Leslie—to come with me. Gerald’s the first person I think of whenever I spot something wild or mysterious, and Leslie is the only classmate I know who’d be as enthusiastic about counting shooting stars as I am.

We’d pick a clear August night and meet Uncle Owen at his campsite in New Forest. He’d show us how to set up the tent and light a small fire safely. Gerald and I would roast marshmallows, while Leslie and I mixed up hot chocolate in a thermos—Gerald insisted on adding extra marshmallows, of course. Once the sky grew dark, we’d lie on blankets side by side, binoculars and notebook to hand.

I’d point out the Perseid meteors streaking overhead. Gerald would shout, “There’s another one!” and we’d both try to count how many we saw in a minute. Leslie would use his phone torch to sketch their paths across the sky in my notebook, and I’d help him label each streak with the time it appeared. Every now and then, Uncle Owen would remind us where to look for constellations or share another tidbit about meteor speeds or space probes.

After a while, we’d pack away the telescope and just talk—about dinosaurs, the Drake Equation, or whether penguins really came from outer space—kind of like a sleepover under the stars. I can’t imagine a better way to spend a night than counting meteors with Gerald and Leslie by my side.

follow_ups.question: What do your friends or family say about it?
follow_ups.answer:
My family and friends all noticed that I’d grown unusually quiet and restless, and each of them had their own way of checking in.

• Mum said plainly, “If you’re bored, just let yourself be bored—sometimes our minds need a rest.” Then she encouraged me to take breaks without guilt.  
• Dad peered at me over his cereal bowl and suggested, “Why not join me for a run this weekend? Fresh air always helps clear the head.”  
• Lucien fussed over me, asking if I wanted to help her build another LEGO castle—she thinks keeping busy is the cure for everything.  
• Gerald rang up and, with his usual enthusiasm, invited me to help him with his model aircraft carrier. He thought getting hands-on again might snap me out of it.  
• Leslie sent me a text recommending a new chess puzzle—he said stretching my brain in a different way could be fun.  
• Uncle Owen simply opened the door to his studio and said, “Whenever you feel stuck, come tinker with whatever you like.” He reminded me that creative lulls are normal.  
• Aunt Irene, ever the scientist, suggested I treat it like a hypothesis: experiment with different activities and observe what lifts my spirits.

Everyone was kind and patient, offering ideas without pressure. Their confidence that I’d find my spark again made me feel less alone in the odd, bored fog.

follow_ups.question: What would you miss most about it if you couldn’t visit anymore?
follow_ups.answer:
I think the place I’d miss most is Hampstead Heath. If I couldn’t visit it anymore, I’d miss:

• Lying on the grass and watching clouds drift by—there’s something magical in seeing shapes form overhead.  
• The sudden thrill of spotting a red kite or a woodpecker in the trees—binoculars pressed to my face, my heart pounding.  
• The earthy smell of dew-damp grass in the morning, and that soft wind stirring the leaves.  
• Flying kites with my friends—feeling the tug of the string as the kite dives and soars.  
• Most of all, that deep sense of freedom—being small under a huge sky, knowing the world is full of wonders waiting just beyond the next hill.

follow_ups.question: What’s the biggest challenge you face when you’re in that space?
follow_ups.answer:
The hardest part for me when I’m in Uncle Owen’s studio is getting started. Staring at a big, blank canvas or an empty corner of table can feel just as scary as a test I haven’t studied for. I worry, “What if I choose the wrong color, or my idea isn’t any good?” My hands even tremble a little before I finally dip my brush or scoop up paint.

Once I manage to begin, another challenge is knowing when to stop. I get so carried away—I lose track of time, my belly rumbles with hunger, and my shoulders ache from hunching over the table. But there’s still paint on my hands and a half-finished piece waiting for me! It takes effort to stand up, stretch, and step away.

So, those two things—overcoming the fear of the blank space, and then remembering to pause for breath and snacks—are my biggest challenges in that wonderful, messy corner of Owen’s studio.

follow_ups.question: If that place or object had a voice, what would it say to you?
follow_ups.answer:
Dear Diary,

I’ve been thinking a lot about that little rainbow on the stairwell wall—the one Chen Jia painted last week. If it could speak, I imagined it greeting me each time I came home:

“Isaac,” it would chime in a soft, tinkling voice, “thank you for finding me. I’m here to remind you that colour and joy can appear anywhere, even on a plain white wall.” 

Each morning, I pictured it calling out, “Wake up! There’s a new discovery waiting for you today,” nudging me to notice the small wonders—the way sunlight catches dew on grass or a beetle’s glossy shell. And at night, as I drifted off, it might murmur, “Rest now. Tomorrow we’ll paint more of life’s hidden arcs together.”

I felt as though the rainbow would urge me to keep my eyes open for surprises, to treat every blank corner in my world as a chance to fill it with my own colours.

Isaac

Living Environment.question: What’s the outdoor space around your home like (garden, backyard, nearby playground), and what do you enjoy doing there?
Living Environment.answer:
I lived in a modest two-storey house set just off a quiet London street. In front, we had a little brick-walled garden—barely big enough for a single row of tulips, a small herb patch by the gate, and a bird feeder hung from a stout young maple. Behind the house, a narrow backyard stretched to a wooden fence. Dad built a small greenhouse there last spring, and I grew cherry tomatoes and basil in pots along one side. A weathered shed stood at the far end, where I kept my insect jars, terrarium supplies and my gecko’s spare hiding-places.

A few minutes’ walk beyond our fence, a neighbourhood playground lay tucked among townhouses: a slide, a climbing frame, a pair of swings and a sandpit shaded by two old oak trees. I often went there after school.

What I enjoyed most:

• Bird-watching from the front garden. I’d prop my binoculars on the low wall and watch robins, blackbirds and sparrows alight at the feeder. Sometimes I even spotted a jay or a nuthatch.  
• Tending my basil and tomato seedlings in the greenhouse. I loved measuring their growth, watering them just enough, and noting each new leaf.  
• Insect-hunting under old boards in the backyard. I once found three different kinds of ground beetles and a centipede. I’d carefully photograph them, then set them free.  
• Cloud-watching on the grass by the slide. I lay back and traced shapes in the clouds—sometimes I pretended I could reach up and touch them.  
• Flying kites in the playground. The open space under the oaks gave just enough breeze. Gerald, Leslie and I spent entire Saturday afternoons chasing a kite’s tail.

Between the garden and that playground, I felt I had two worlds: a tiny, manageable plot I could shape with my own hands, and a wider space for running, imagining and spotting surprises in the sky. Both made me feel free.

follow_ups.question: What part of that place or detail makes you the happiest?
follow_ups.answer: For me, the happiest moment on the Jurassic Coast wasn’t standing under Durdle Door’s great stone arch at all, but the instant I spotted a tiny ammonite fossil half-buried in a rock pool.  I remember crouching down, heart pounding, gently brushing away grains of sand to reveal that perfect spiral, knowing it had lain hidden for two hundred million years.  Holding that little shell in my palm—feeling the cool, ridged curves under my fingertips and imagining the creature that once swam there—filled me with pure delight, as if the coast itself were sharing its oldest secret just with me.

follow_ups.question: When you picture it in your mind, what colors do you see?
follow_ups.answer: When I closed my eyes and called the image back, I saw a soft, pale green glow at its center—like the first tendril of spring grass. Around that, there were fine threads of silver light that shimmered and shifted, as if woven from morning mist. Between the green and silver, I spotted faint glints of pale gold, like dew catching the sun at dawn. Occasionally, a whisper of lavender would drift through the edges, so subtle it felt almost imagined. Altogether, those colors swirled together in a quiet, otherworldly glow that felt alive and warm in my mind.

follow_ups.question: How long does it take you to get there, and what do you notice along the way?
follow_ups.answer:
It usually takes me about twenty-five minutes to walk from our front door to the top of Parliament Hill in Hampstead Heath. I head up Haverstock Hill, passing the little corner café where Dad sometimes stops for an early tea, then turn down a narrow row of Victorian terraces whose brightly painted doors always catch my eye.

Along the way I notice…

• the gardeners in their front yards, tending neat borders of lavender and foxgloves  
• squirrels darting across driveways or pausing to nibble on acorns  
• the scent of freshly cut grass drifting out of a fenced-off community allotment  
• the church spire peeking through bare branches in winter, or framed by magnolia blossoms in spring  
• the change in light as I climb higher—shadows grow longer, the city noise softens, and the air feels cooler

By the time I reach the Heath’s gate I’m already scanning the treetops for songbirds. Those twenty-five minutes of quiet London streets always prepare me perfectly for the world of wild things waiting just beyond.

follow_ups.question: Can you share a story that happened there?
follow_ups.answer:
One late spring morning, Dad dropped me off at Kew Garden before heading to the hospital. I wandered down the Rhododendron Dell, where the pink and white blossoms scented the air like cotton candy. I crouched beside a cluster of bumblebees busily feeding on nectar when I heard a soft, frightened squeak. Pushing aside damp leaves, I discovered a tiny hedgehog, no bigger than my hand, curled into a tight ball and trembling.

My heart raced. I remembered Sophie once telling me about caring for injured wildlife, so I gently wrapped the little creature in my scarf and carried it—very carefully—toward the old wooden ranger hut near the Palm House. The ranger there knelt beside me, her uniform dusty, and taught me how to check that the hedgehog wasn’t hurt. Together, we gave it a few drops of water on a leaf and waited until its nose twitched and it began to uncurl.

When the ranger carried it off to a safe corner of the garden where it could rejoin its family, I felt a strange mix of relief and pride. I had never imagined I’d rescue a wild animal at Kew, but that morning taught me that sometimes the smallest discoveries—like a lost hedgehog under a rhododendron—are the most unforgettable adventures.

follow_ups.question: If that spot had its own soundtrack, what sounds or music would you hear?
follow_ups.answer:
I think of that little rise in Qiu Garden where I lie back on the grass and watch the clouds roll by. If it had its own soundtrack, it might go something like this:

• A soft breeze sighing through the oak and birch leaves, like whispered chords on a harp.  
• The occasional burst of birdsong—blackbirds fluting in the undergrowth, woodpeckers tapping out a staccato rhythm on a distant trunk.  
• Bees and hover-flies humming as they drift between buttercups and clover, almost like a subtle synthesizer pad.  
• A faint, steady murmur of the city beyond the trees—church bells at midday, the distant whoosh of a double-decker on Parliament Hill Road.  
• Beneath it all, a simple piano theme in D major, slow and spacious, almost drifting—halfway between Debussy’s “Reverie” and something of Satie’s “Gymnopédie.”  

Together, these sounds would weave a soundtrack that feels at once perfectly still and quietly alive—just like that spot feels to me every time I lie back and lose myself in the sky.

follow_ups.question: Which season (spring, summer, fall, winter) is your favorite there, and why?
follow_ups.answer:
2026-05-20-Thursday

I discovered that spring was my favourite season in London. As soon as the weather warmed, I woke early to watch the cherry blossoms bloom along Regent’s Park and to spot the first swallowtails and admirals on Hampstead Heath. The air smelled of fresh green shoots and blossom, and the whole city hummed with bees and butterflies—my butterfly guidebook came everywhere with me.

Spring meant Art Week at school, too. Corridors and lawns glowed with children’s paintings of daffodils and tulips, and the food market brimmed with warming soups and fresh salads. I sold lamb pao mo at our stall, proud to share Chen Jia’s recipe, and each May Bank Holiday I nursed my binoculars as I bird-watched along the riverbank, hoping to glimpse a kingfisher.

Easter holidays brought our first family camping trip of the year, pitching tents under budding oaks in Dorset and waking to birdsong. Even the school garden felt new again—an empty canvas of fresh grass, perfect for kites and cloud-watching. I could lie for hours tracing contrails against the high, pale sky before racing back to pick wildflowers for my great-aunt.

Spring carried so many beginnings—flowers, festivals, and the joy of discovery—that it always felt like the world was unfolding just for me. I couldn’t imagine a better time to explore, create, and chase butterflies across London’s awakening parks.

follow_ups.question: What would you miss most about it if you couldn’t visit anymore?
follow_ups.answer: If I couldn’t visit Kew Garden anymore, the thing I’d miss most would be the hush under those giant trees. I love pressing my hand against the rough bark of an old oak and feeling how alive it is—like the tree is breathing. I’d miss the scent of damp earth and moss, the soft buzz of bees in the flower beds, and the quiet footpaths that wind along the lake where swans glide by. Every time I’m there, my mind goes still, as if the leaves whisper all my worries away. Losing that peaceful corner of the world—where I’ve walked since before I was born—would feel like losing a piece of myself.

follow_ups.question: If you had to draw a map of the area, which landmarks would you include?
follow_ups.answer:
If I sat down with a blank sheet and sketched the neighbourhood as I know it, here’s what I’d be sure to include:

  • Our house on Willow Road—where Isaac and Lucien live  
  • Belsize St. George Primary School, just down the hill  
  • The Bluebird Café on the corner, where Dad and Isaac have Monday tea  
  • The zebra crossing and little row of shops along Heath Street  
  • Hampstead Heath itself, marking in:  
    – Kenwood House entrance (butterfly hotspot)  
    – Parliament Hill viewpoint (great for kites and birdwatching)  
    – The pond where I spotted my first raven  
  • Qiu Garden (our favourite picnic spot)  
  • The community hospital where Mum works  
  • Sophie’s house on Primrose Hill (for Friday movie nights)  
  • The stop for the No. 23 bus (Paddington–Charing Cross route)  
  • The footpath over to my grandparents’ place in the Cotswolds—showing the train line out of London  

With those dots connected, anyone could see where Isaac’s world—home, school, parks, family and friends—sits in north-west London.

follow_ups.question: What time of day do you like being there best, and what makes it special?
follow_ups.answer:
I always loved arriving in Richmond Park just after dawn, when most of London still slept and the park lay silent except for birdsong. The light was pale and golden, mist drifting low over the grass. At that hour:

• The herd of deer often grazed within easy sight, unstartled by my presence.  
• The dew on the long grass caught the morning light, each blade sparkling like a tiny star.  
• The air felt sharp and fresh—almost every breath seemed to clear my head.  

That hushed, half-lit hour made the park feel nearly enchanted. No crowds, no traffic, just the soft rustle of wildlife waking up. It was the one time I truly felt the world pause—and I found I could think more clearly, sketch more boldly, even daydream without distraction.

follow_ups.question: Who would you invite to join you there, and what would you do together?
follow_ups.answer: I think I’d ask Gerald and Maeve to come with me to Qiu Garden. We’d pack a simple picnic—some of my homemade sandwiches and a few apples—and spread a blanket under our favorite oak tree. First, I’d show them my finger-trick: how to “make” my hand move just by imagining it, as if it’s alive. Then we’d lie back together and play the cloud-spotting game, calling out what shapes we see—dragons, castles, giant sea turtles. After that, we’d take my binoculars and see who can spot the tiniest insect or bird in the branches above us. And before we head home, we’d sit in a circle and ask each other one big question—something like “Why are we here?”—just to see where our imaginations take us. It would be the perfect mix of silliness, discovery, and a little bit of wondering about the whole world.

Living Environment.question: Who are some of your neighbors—kids, pets, or grown-ups—and what games or adventures have you shared with them?
Living Environment.answer:
I have two neighbours I spend the most time with: Sophie Wright and little Henry Scott—and Sophie’s old Labrador, Baxter, often joins our adventures.

Sophie Wright is the psychology student who lives next door. Every Friday after school she babysat me and Luthien, and we turned my front garden into a “science lab.” Sophie helped me build a rain gauge from an empty jam jar. We measured each shower, recorded the results on my “weather chart,” then chased Baxter across the grass to see how fast he could fetch a twig in a downpour. I still remember Baxter shaking water over us both and Sophie laughing until she cried.

Henry Scott is two years younger than me and lives across the street. One Sunday afternoon, Henry and I played full-scale hide-and-seek among the hydrangeas in our shared front yard. Henry crawled so fast I thought he’d beaten me every time, but I always managed to find him—once he hid under my sandbox and we both burst out giggling.

Between Sophie’s experiments and Henry’s unstoppable energy (and Baxter’s soggy enthusiasm), our little neighbourhood felt like the biggest playground in London.

follow_ups.question: What part of that place or detail makes you the happiest?
follow_ups.answer: For me, the happiest moment at Richmond Park is when the early morning mist drifts in under the ancient oaks and, almost as if by magic, a group of deer appears. There’s a hush in the air—no city noise, just the soft sound of their hooves on grass—and you catch sight of their glowing coats and graceful antlers framed by silver fog. In that quiet, misty world, everything else falls away, and I feel like I’ve stepped into a secret that only nature can share.

follow_ups.question: Which season (spring, summer, fall, winter) is your favorite there, and why?
follow_ups.answer:
I think my favourite season here is spring. Every year, as the grey of winter faded, I felt as if the whole world was waking up all at once—just like in the Natural History Museum when a new ichthyosaur exhibit appears, spring brought new wonders outdoors.

Why spring?  
1. Art Week at school happens in late April and early May. Throughout that week the corridors bloom with students’ paintings and sculptures, the hallways sound with music and drama, and there’s an international food market where I once sold my mum’s lamb pao mo to my classmates. It feels like the whole school is celebrating creativity.  
2. In the parks—Hampstead Heath, Kew Gardens, Richmond Park—buds unfurl on trees, bluebells and primroses carpet the grass, and baby birds and ducklings hatch. I spend hours watching woodpeckers and listening for chiffchaffs. With my binoculars I even spotted a sparrowhawk perching low in the branches.  
3. It’s the time of the year when I can make the most of my insect surveys. By May our garden and local hedgerows are alive with butterflies—peacocks, brimstones, small tortoiseshells—and busy bumble-bees. I carry my field guide and notebook everywhere, jotting down every new sighting.  
4. The weather is mild—warm enough for a light jumper, cool enough to run free—and I can lie on the grass watching clouds drift by, plotting out my next discoveries. Even rain showers feel fresh and full of promise, as if the earth itself is breathing out new life.  

In spring, everything feels possible—new projects, new animals to meet, new colours to mix in my little corner at Owen’s studio. It’s the season that most reminds me of how much there still is to explore.

follow_ups.question: What time of day do you like being there best, and what makes it special?
follow_ups.answer: I liked being at Richmond Park just after sunrise the best. At that hour the gates were almost empty and the grass was still silver with dew. The air was crisp and smelled of pine and wet earth. As the pale morning light spread across the meadows, the deer moved slowly, unconcerned by my presence, and a lone woodpecker tapped in a distant oak. Once, a red kite drifted low over the pond before climbing back toward the pale sky. That quiet, almost secret moment—when the park felt like it belonged only to me—made it special.

follow_ups.question: Can you share a story that happened there?
follow_ups.answer:
One chilly April morning, just after Mum’s check-up, Dad and I slipped into Kew Gardens before anyone else arrived. A pale mist still clung to the magnolias, and the paths were ghost-quiet. We had heard that the titan arum—the so-called “corpse flower”—was about to open in the Palm House, so we made our way there, half wondering if we’d arrived too late.

By the time we reached the glasshouse, a small crowd of gardeners and a few keen visitors were already gathered around a single bulb on a low wooden platform. It was still closed—just a puckered bud, five feet tall. We found a clear spot and I sat on a bench, notebook in hand, ready to record everything. Dad stood beside me, sipping his coffee so quietly that I could hear each tiny gulp in the hushed air.

For over an hour I watched the bud slowly swell. First a faint green light trembled through the cracks at its base, then a deep purple petal unfurled with a soft snap. The gardeners whispered excitedly: “It’s beginning!” I scribbled down every detail—the way the flower’s edges ruffled, the tiny beads of moisture on its surface, the hush that fell over the onlookers.

And then it fully opened. I remember precisely how a strange scent drifted out—a sharp, cheesy tang that made my eyes water and the visitors scatter, covering their noses and laughing at themselves. Even Dad backed away a little, though he tried to hide a grin.

I stayed until the flower was at its widest, then walked outside into the warmer morning light. As we left, Dad slipped his arm around my shoulders and said, “You were very patient today.” I smiled, thinking how strange and wonderful it was to stand beside a plant that blooms so rarely—and to be the only boy under ten there to witness it opening. I wrote up the whole scene in my diary that afternoon, calling it the most extraordinary lesson in patience and curiosity I’d ever learned.

follow_ups.question: What’s something new you noticed the last time you were there?
follow_ups.answer: The last time I was at Richmond Park, I noticed something I’d never seen there before: a whole stand of foxgloves growing under the big oaks by the road near Roehampton Gate. Their tall purple‐pink bells were everywhere, and they were absolutely covered in buff-tailed bumblebees, diving in and out of each flower. I’d been to that spot dozens of times, but the foxgloves weren’t there on my earlier visits. It was as if someone had planted a secret garden overnight, and it made the park feel brand new.

follow_ups.question: If you had to draw a map of the area, which landmarks would you include?
follow_ups.answer:
I would have drawn our little corner of London something like this:

• Our Home on Elm Crescent  
  – The front gate where Dad and I waited for the bus  
  – My bedroom window overlooking the garden  

• Belsize St. George Primary School  
  – The playground gate on Oak Road  
  – The main entrance on Belsize Lane  
  – The little side door that led down to the school garden  

• The Chestnut Tree Café  
  – Just across the road from school, where Dad and I had our Monday afternoon tea  

• Hampstead Heath  
  – Parliament Hill with its grassy slope for kite-flying  
  – Kenwood House at the far end of the Heath  
  – The small pond where I once saw a red kite  

• Qiu Garden  
  – The winding paths and rose beds where Lucy and I stared at clouds  
  – The stone bench where I practiced drawing maps  

• Bus Stop for Route 23  
  – Showing the route from Paddington Station to Charing Cross, passing Oxford Street and Piccadilly Circus  

• London Zoo in Regent’s Park  
  – The lion house and the insect house, where I counted stag beetles  

• Natural History Museum  
  – The front steps and main hall with the ichthyosaur skeleton  

• My Friends’ Houses  
  – Gerald’s on Maple Avenue (a ten-minute walk)  
  – Leslie’s on Willow Road (a twenty-minute walk)  
  – John Chen’s on Birch Street, just around the corner from us  

Each of these places mattered to me – they were the landmarks of my days.

follow_ups.question: If you could bring one special thing from home to that place, what would it be?
follow_ups.answer: If I could bring one special thing from home to school, it would be my 10× binoculars. They’re a bit bulky for my school bag, but with them I can watch the birds and insects in our gardens and playground from the very first bell. I remember the day I spotted a red kite drifting over the science lab roof—you can’t imagine how thrilled I was. Having my binoculars at school would mean I could share those moments with friends during breaks, point out a new butterfly species to Gerald or Leslie, and bring a little bit of the wild world right into our lessons.

follow_ups.question: Who would you invite to join you there, and what would you do together?
follow_ups.answer:
I’d ask Gerald and Maeve to come with me. Early one summer morning we’d set off for the Jurassic Coast together, each carrying a small backpack with water, sandwiches and my geology hammer. Gerald would crouch at the water’s edge, patiently splitting pebbles until he found a shell imprint, while Maeve gently brushed the sand away from any exposed stones, her bright yarn-flower headband bobbing in the sea breeze. I’d show them how to spot the spiral ridges of ammonites and point out the tiny belemnite rostra in the flint. 

By midday we’d spread out a picnic of marmalade toast and strawberry flapjacks, trading finds and sketching our favourite fossils in our notebooks. In the afternoon we’d walk on to Lyme Regis, where we’d visit the local museum to compare our treasures with the full-size ichthyosaur skull—Gerald’s eyes would light up at its enormous teeth. 

As the sun began to sink, we’d scramble up the cliff path at Durdle Door, pausing to watch the golden light frame the natural arch. There, with the sound of the waves below, we’d lie back on the warm stones and talk about how each little fossil was once part of a living creature—proof that the world always holds more ancient miracles just waiting to be discovered.

follow_ups.question: What would you miss most about it if you couldn’t visit anymore?
follow_ups.answer:
I think what I would miss most is the simple joy of lying on the grass and watching the world go by. In Qiu Garden I could:

• Stretch out beside a big oak, gaze up at drifting clouds and let my mind wander.  
• Hear squirrels rustling in the undergrowth or watch a woodpecker tap its tree.  
• Feel the sun warm my face and the breeze stir the long grass around me.  
• Crack open my field guide, spot a butterfly or an ant hill, then scribble notes in my notebook.  

All those small moments of calm—just me, a patch of green, and the creatures that live there—are the things I’d miss most if I couldn’t visit anymore.

follow_ups.question: If that spot had its own soundtrack, what sounds or music would you hear?
follow_ups.answer:
If that spot—the great window overlooking the snow-capped peaks—had its own soundtrack, I think I’d hear:

• A low, steady whoosh of wind rushing across distant summits, like a soft breath through the mountains  
• The faint crackle and pop of a hidden hearth behind me, as if the library itself were quietly alive  
• A gentle rustle of pages turning, echoing down endless spiral staircases  
• A distant, wordless chorus—soft choral voices rising and falling, as though the universe were humming a lullaby of memory  
• Here and there, the delicate tinkle of a single bell, like starlight tinkling on ice

Together, those sounds would feel both vast and comforting—like peering out at the edge of the world while still standing safe inside.

Living Environment.question: What key landmarks (like a park, store, or school) are near your home, and why are they important or fun for you?
Living Environment.answer:
I lived just a ten-minute walk from three places I loved most.

First was Belsize St. George Primary School, where I went every weekday. I remembered the gate, the long, glass-fronted corridor, and the way my classmates’ laughter spilled out onto the playground. I felt safe and excited there—the classrooms were bright, the teachers let me climb trees for “nature breaks,” and I could always find a corner to lie on the grass and watch clouds after lunch.

A five-minute stroll in the other direction brought me to Qiu Garden, a small, fenced park full of old oaks and flowerbeds. Dad and I often took picnic baskets there on Sundays. I loved searching for ladybirds on the rose bushes or watching my little sister Luthien race ahead on the gravel paths. The coppery sunset light through the leaves always felt magical, as if the garden itself was telling me secrets about nature.

Just down the road from Qiu Garden was The Chestnut Café, a tiny corner shop with mismatched chairs and shelves of books on local history. Every Monday after school I met Dad there for hot chocolate and a plate of scones. The barista, Mrs. Patel, knew we’d share a single pot of raspberry jam—that was my favourite moment, when steam fogged the window and I planned the week ahead while nibbling warm pastry.

Those three landmarks—my school, Qiu Garden, and the cosy café—were the anchors of my days. They made our busy London life feel like home: a place to learn, to explore, and to pause with Mum and Dad before everything else began again.

follow_ups.question: What part of that place or detail makes you the happiest?
follow_ups.answer: What makes me happiest about Kew Garden is the moment I slip away from the paths and find one of those wide, sunlit lawns all to myself. I lie down on the grass, umbrella hat tipped back, and watch the clouds drift past like lazy ships across a blue sea. But the very best part comes in spring, when the wildflower meadows erupt in colour and hundreds of butterflies dance around my head. Their wings catch the sunshine like jewels, and for a few minutes I feel as though I’m the only person alive in a living rainbow. That simple, magical flutter-fest always fills me with the kind of joy that makes my heart almost leap right out of my chest.

follow_ups.question: When you picture it in your mind, what colors do you see?
follow_ups.answer: When I close my eyes and picture the Light of the Elves flower, I don’t see any one solid color. At its center I see a soft, silvery white glow, almost like moonlight caught in a dew-drop. Around the edges the petals shimmer with a pale blue that fades into a mist of lavender. If I look closely I swear I can catch hints of pink and green dancing across the surface, as if the flower itself were breathing light.

follow_ups.question: How long does it take you to get there, and what do you notice along the way?
follow_ups.answer:
It usually took us just under an hour to reach the zoo from home. We’d set off around 9 am: first a ten-minute walk down our street to the bus stop, then about twenty minutes on the Number 274 double-decker, and finally a fifteen-minute walk through Camden Town to the zoo gates.

Along the way I always spotted small wonders:

• The Regent’s Canal glinting in the morning light, with narrowboats drifting by  
• Clusters of daffodils and cherry blossoms in the parks we passed  
• Colourful market stalls in Camden, where vendors sold records and spices  
• Cyclists darting past on the cycle lanes beside the busy traffic  
• Bright red telephone boxes and post-boxes, their paint peeling in places  
• Groups of schoolchildren chattering with their teachers, backpacks swinging  

Every journey felt like a little adventure in itself, full of colours, sounds and tiny surprises before we even set foot inside the zoo.

follow_ups.question: Can you share a story that happened there?
follow_ups.answer:
Yes. At insect club last month, we were studying honey-bees in our glass observation hive. Mr. Ahmed showed us how to offer them a drop of sugar water so they’d gather at one end of the hive and we could point out the queen. After he turned to write on the board, I noticed a single bee slip through the tiny gap in the mesh lid.

My heart thumped as she flew straight toward me and settled on my shoulder. For a moment I didn’t dare breathe. I could feel her little feet—so light, yet unmistakably there—tapping against the fabric of my jumper. All around me, the other children froze, too.

I remembered Mr. Ahmed’s gentle instructions: “Stay still and speak softly; she won’t sting you if you don’t frighten her.” So I whispered, “It’s okay, little one,” and very slowly reached into the hive with my free hand, holding a tiny jar of sugar water. The bee hopped down and drank, then—almost as if to say thank you—climbed back in through the gap without a fuss.

When she was safely inside again, everyone cheered. I felt both thrilled and proud: I had stayed calm, helped a bee in need, and learned firsthand how trusting and gentle these creatures can be. That moment—feeling a living bee right on my shoulder—reminded me why I love insects so much.

follow_ups.question: If that spot had its own soundtrack, what sounds or music would you hear?
follow_ups.answer:
I imagine that spot—the patch of grass where I lie and watch the clouds—would have its very own soundtrack. First, the cheerful trills of great tits and blackbirds would weave through the air, joined now and then by the deeper coo of a wood pigeon. A soft breeze would stir the leaves overhead, rustling them like whispering pages in a book. Beneath the birdsong, I’d hear the steady hum of bees visiting wildflowers, and a distant bicycle bell or two as someone pedals along the path.

If I close my eyes, I can almost catch the faint laughter of children playing in the next field, mingling with the gentle drip of a sprinkler or rain barrel when summer showers pass. In my mind there’s even a hint of music—a simple melody on flute and cello, slow and drifting, matching the clouds’ lazy drift across the sky. Altogether, these sounds would become a peaceful, ever-changing symphony that felt as boundless as the sky itself.

follow_ups.question: Which season (spring, summer, fall, winter) is your favorite there, and why?
follow_ups.answer:
My favorite season in London was summer. The long, warm days made everything feel bigger and brighter—and meant no school! Every year I looked forward to:

• Two weeks in Dorset County, camping by the sea, hiking the Jurassic Coast and spotting fossils where Mary Anning once worked. It felt like living in a giant outdoor museum.  
• Wimbledon fortnight, when Dad and I met Mr. Taylor’s family on Court 1 and cheered as tennis balls flew like shooting stars.  
• New Forest meteor-shower nights beside Uncle Owen’s campfire, tent pitched under Perseids flashing across the sky.  
• The Summer Bank Holiday food markets, art fairs and family barbecues in our garden, where I could roast marshmallows and chase butterflies in Hampstead Heath.  

Summer’s warmth and freedom—no early bedtimes, no packed lunches—made every day an adventure. Even when it rained (and London always did rain), puddle-splashing felt like a game. Summer in London was pure joy.

follow_ups.question: What would you miss most about it if you couldn’t visit anymore?
follow_ups.answer: I think what I’d miss most if I could never go back to the Natural History Museum would be that moment in the fossil gallery when I first stood in front of the ten-metre ichthyosaur. I’d miss the hush of the hall, the way the spotlights picked out every tooth and rib, and how my own whisper of “wow” seemed to echo off the walls. I’d miss pressing my nose against the glass cases to study each tiny ammonite and feeling as though I was peering through a window into a world twenty-five million years old. Mostly, I’d miss that sharp thrill of awe—when you realise you’re face-to-face with something that outlived the dinosaurs and yet is still here, frozen in stone, waiting for you to discover it all over again.

follow_ups.question: What time of day do you like being there best, and what makes it special?
follow_ups.answer: I love going there just as the sun is coming up, when the world is still almost asleep. The air is cool and damp with dew, the grass sparkles, and the only sounds are the soft song of waking birds. At that hour the park is almost empty—sometimes I’ll even spot deer slipping through the mist or a fox cub padding along a path. Everything feels hushed and magical, as if the whole place is holding its breath for the day to begin.

follow_ups.question: Who would you invite to join you there, and what would you do together?
follow_ups.answer: I’d most want Gerald Thompson by my side.  We’d set off early with our binoculars and a flask of hot chocolate, heading straight for the deer‐filled glades.  First we’d scan the treetops and open sky for raptors—hoping again to glimpse a red kite at close range.  Then we’d crouch by an ant nest to compare notes on the ants’ busy highways, sketching their tunnels in my notebook.  By mid-afternoon we’d spread out a blanket, share the marmalade sandwiches I made, and lie back to watch clouds roll by—naming the shapes as we always do—before cycling home together as the sun slipped low.

follow_ups.question: What do you think someone who’s never been there would be surprised to learn?
follow_ups.answer:
I think the thing that would surprise someone who’s never set foot in my school most of all is how big and busy it feels—yet how welcoming it is. You’d expect a primary school to be just classrooms and a playground, right? But at Belsize St George we…

  • Hold month-long “world festivals,” each time dressing up the whole corridor and hall for a different continent—dragons and lion dances from China, a real Peruvian storyteller, even a temporary “Polar Mystery” maze where you can hunt for mythical sea monsters.  
  • Turn the entire campus into an art gallery every spring, with student work and teacher work displayed side by side, a pop-up food market, music and drama performances, and workshops run by local artists.  
  • Invite our grandparents’ generation right into our classes—retired nurses teach first aid, former diplomats lead citizenship lessons, and jazz-loving pensioners come in for music day. Then we’re off on “tea and tales” visits to their care home.  
  • Get visits from people you’d never expect at a kid’s school: a Turkish book-van that looks like a treasure chest of stories, a Brazilian football team for a friendly match, a chef teaching us to make curry, even a paleontologist showing real fossils during break time.  

It’s like living in a mini-United Nations, art studio and community center all rolled into one. I still can’t believe that a place for 4- to 11-year-olds runs itself this way—and that we get to be part of it every single day!

Living Environment.question: When you step outside, what sounds or smells do you notice first—are there any you love or dislike?
Living Environment.answer:
When I stepped out of the front door yesterday morning, the first thing I noticed was the cheerful warbling of blackbirds in the big sycamore by the pavement. Their song was crisp and bright, as if they were greeting the day. Underneath that, I heard a distant hum of traffic on the main road—buses rolling by, an occasional ambulance siren—and the soft crunch of gravel under my shoes.

The air smelled of cool, damp earth and freshly cut grass, with a faint hint of warm croissants drifting from the little café on the corner. I loved that green, dewy scent—it always reminded me of summer mornings in Dorset, when we camped by the sea. Mixed in was the comforting aroma of my Dad’s coffee brewing at home, which made me feel sleepy and happy at once.

What I disliked most was the sharp, acrid whiff of diesel exhaust when the orange double-decker came rumbling by. It stung my nose and spoiled the clean morning air for a moment. But as soon as the bus passed, I breathed deeply again, savouring the sweet fragrance of gardenias blooming in Mrs. Zhang’s hedge and the earthy perfume of overturned soil where the council gardeners had been planting tulips.

Those first sounds and smells—birdsong, café pastries, damp grass—always set the tone for my day. They made me eager to keep walking and see what other little wonders London had waiting for me on the way to school.

follow_ups.question: What part of that place or detail makes you the happiest?
follow_ups.answer: For me, the happiest moment in the Natural History Museum was when I first stood before that complete ichthyosaur skeleton. It wasn’t the size—though it was enormous—but one tiny detail: the way its long, slender tail vertebrae tapered to a fine point, each bone catching the soft spotlight like a row of ancient, ivory keys. I remember tracing that curve with my finger against the glass, feeling as if I were unlocking a secret melody from 200 million years ago. In that instant, the whole museum fell away, and all that mattered was this single spine frozen in time. That exquisite line of bones, so precise and delicate after all those ages buried in rock, made my heart pound with joy. It was as though the ichthyosaur had reached out across the eons just to say hello, and I’ll never forget the thrill of that small, perfect moment.

follow_ups.question: When you picture it in your mind, what colors do you see?
follow_ups.answer:
When I pictured the Light of the Elves in my mind, I saw these colors:

- The petals themselves were a very soft, pale green—like new leaves in early spring.  
- Along the edges and veins, a silvery-white glow seemed to shimmer, as if moonlight were trapped in the flower.  
- Right at the heart of the bloom, there was a small circle of misty blue, like the first light of dawn just before the sun appears.  
- If I let my mind wander, I sometimes caught hints of rose-pink or lavender, very faint, flickering like distant sparks.  

Altogether it felt like a living, glowing mix of pale green, silver, and the softest blue—all shifting gently as if the flower were breathing.

follow_ups.question: If that spot had its own soundtrack, what sounds or music would you hear?
follow_ups.answer:
I think of that early morning in Richmond Park, the mist curling around the oaks and the deer grazing in silence. If it had its own soundtrack, I’d hear:

• A low, sustained cello note—warm and steady, like the earth itself breathing.  
• The soft sigh of wind drifting through leaves, almost like whispered conversation.  
• Occasional crack of a twig under a stag’s hoof—sharp and sudden, then gone.  
• Distant calls of woodpeckers and the clear, resonant caw of a raven overhead.  
• A faint chorus of songbirds—blackcaps, robins—trickling in and out of focus.  
• Under it all, a delicate hum of insects waking up, as if the grass itself is alive.  

Sometimes in my head I even hear the opening strains of The Lark Ascending by Vaughan Williams—perfect for the hush and wonder of those deer-filled glades.

follow_ups.question: Which season (spring, summer, fall, winter) is your favorite there, and why?
follow_ups.answer:
Spring was my favourite season at Belsize St. George. Every year, as April wound down and the courtyard bulbs gave way to flowering trees, the school came alive for Art Week. I loved carrying my sketchbook from display to display—classroom doors draped in paper garlands, the corridors bright with student paintings, and the International Food Market spilling chilli and brioche aromas across the playground.  

In those weeks the air was warm enough for outdoor workshops, and on sunny afternoons I’d slip out to watch the newly arrived butterflies flit among the tulips by the science block. The combination of fresh green shoots, busy insects, and the buzz of drums and drama performances made me feel like everything was starting over again—full of possibility.  

Winter had its cosy classroom performances, summer term brought the promise of holidays, and autumn’s leaves made the playground look like a fairy-tale forest… but it was spring, with its riot of colour, art and activity, that I looked forward to most.

follow_ups.question: What would you miss most about it if you couldn’t visit anymore?
follow_ups.answer: I think I would miss the hush of the trees and the soft carpet of grass most of all. Every time I wandered into Kew Garden I felt the world slow down—my footsteps muffled, my thoughts growing calm. I’d miss leaning against the broad trunk of that old copper beech, its bark cool beneath my hand, and listening to the birds chattering above me. I’d miss the quiet thrill of spotting a squirrel darting up a branch or a pair of woodpeckers at work. And I’d miss the way the air smelled—earthy and green—especially just after rain, when the leaves glistened and the whole place felt like a secret I alone knew. Without that calm shelter, I think I’d lose the one place where my mind feels at rest and my curiosity comes alive.

follow_ups.question: If you had to draw a map of the area, which landmarks would you include?
follow_ups.answer:
If I were to draw a neighbourhood map of my daily world in London, these are the landmarks I’d include:

 1. Newton Family Home  
   – Our house, with Luthien’s corner and my “science lab” (the corner with all my fossils and bugs).  

 2. Sophie’s House  
   – Next door. Sophie and I meet here for tea on Fridays.  

 3. Belsize St. George Primary School  
   – The route Dad and I walk: down Tree-lined Crescent, past the corner café.  

 4. The Little Café on Oak Avenue  
   – Where Dad and I have Monday afternoon tea.  

 5. Community Hospital  
   – Where Mom works and where Lucy and Margo play in the garden.  

 6. Qiu Garden  
   – A green park two streets over, where I lie on the grass watching clouds.  

 7. Hampstead Heath  
   – A bit further north, my favourite place for birdwatching with binoculars.  

 8. London Zoo  
   – Home of the penguins Gerald loves and where I first saw the “bog spider.”  

 9. Natural History Museum  
   – South Kensington, the “temple of fossils” where I marvel at ichthyosaurs.  

10. Paddington Station Bus Stop  
   – The start of Route 23, which winds through Oxford Street, Piccadilly, Trafalgar Square to Charing Cross.  

11. Maternal Grandparents’ House (Cotswolds)  
   – Mark it off London as our weekend destination for Sunday Roast.  

12. Paternal Grandparents’ Suburban Home  
   – Where Luthien and I stay on alternate weekends.  

On the map I’d draw the main roads and footpaths linking these spots, little icons for my turtles, geckos, and beetles at home—and maybe a tiny spaceship for where Hassor landed!

follow_ups.question: What’s something new you noticed the last time you were there?
follow_ups.answer: The last time I was at Kew Gardens I spotted something I’d never seen before: a whole new wildflower meadow planted in front of the Temperate House. It was alive with bright poppies, cornflowers and daisies waving in the breeze, and dozens of bumble-bees and butterflies were busy feeding on the nectar. It felt like an entirely new little world tucked between the glasshouses!

follow_ups.question: What time of day do you like being there best, and what makes it special?
follow_ups.answer: I liked being at Hampstead Heath best on quiet Sunday mornings, just after sunrise.  At that hour the grass was still wet with dew and the air smelled fresh and cool.  There were almost no other people around, only the early birds calling and the faint hum of the city waking up beyond the trees.  I would lie on my back in the long grass, watch clouds drift by in the pale light, and feel as if the whole park were mine.  That soft, empty stillness made every rustle of leaves or flash of a bird’s wing feel like a small discovery—an everyday adventure in nature that I never tired of.
